Literature Review: Networked control systems (NCS) have emerged as a critical area of research and application in the past two decades, integrating control theory with communication networks to address complex challenges in various domains. This literature review explores the key developments, theoretical insights, and practical implications of NCS, focusing on the interplay between control and communication layers, as well as the role of information in estimation and control processes.The foundation of NCS research can be traced back to the early 2000s when researchers began to recognize the importance of communication constraints in control systems. Hespanha et al. (2007) provided a comprehensive survey of NCS, highlighting the challenges posed by network-induced delays, packet dropouts, and limited bandwidth. Their work laid the groundwork for understanding the impact of communication imperfections on control performance and stability.As the field progressed, researchers focused on developing robust control strategies that could maintain system stability and performance in the presence of communication uncertainties. Zhang et al. (2013) proposed a novel approach to NCS design using model predictive control (MPC) techniques, demonstrating improved performance in the face of network delays and packet losses. This work exemplified the trend towards adaptive control strategies that could dynamically adjust to changing network conditions.The concept of cyber-physical systems (CPS) emerged as a natural extension of NCS, emphasizing the tight integration of computational and physical processes. Lee (2008) provided a seminal paper on the challenges and opportunities in CPS research, highlighting the need for new modeling paradigms and design methodologies to address the complexities of these systems. This work sparked a surge of interest in CPS across various application domains, from smart grids to autonomous vehicles.One of the key challenges in NCS and CPS is decentralized estimation and control, particularly in distributed sensing and communication systems. Mateos and Giannakis (2012) presented a comprehensive framework for distributed estimation in sensor networks, addressing issues of scalability and robustness in large-scale systems. Their work demonstrated the potential of decentralized approaches to overcome the limitations of centralized control in complex networked environments.The role of information in NCS has been a central theme in recent research, with particular attention given to the value of event timing in control processes. Astrom and Bernhardsson (2002) introduced the concept of event-triggered control, demonstrating its potential to reduce communication requirements while maintaining control performance. This seminal work inspired numerous subsequent studies on event-triggered and self-triggered control strategies in NCS.Building on this foundation, Heemels et al. (2012) provided a comprehensive survey of event-triggered and self-triggered control systems, synthesizing theoretical results and practical implementations. Their work highlighted the potential of these approaches to optimize resource utilization in NCS while maintaining desired control objectives.The information-theoretic aspects of NCS have also gained significant attention in recent years. Nair et al. (2007) explored the fundamental limits of stabilization under communication constraints, establishing connections between control theory and information theory. Their work provided important insights into the minimum data rates required for stabilization in various control scenarios.As NCS applications have expanded into safety-critical domains such as autonomous driving and industrial automation, security concerns have become increasingly important. Cardenas et al. (2008) presented a comprehensive analysis of security challenges in cyber-physical systems, highlighting the need for integrated approaches to address both cyber and physical vulnerabilities. This work underscored the importance of considering security as a fundamental aspect of NCS design.Recent developments in machine learning and artificial intelligence have opened new avenues for enhancing NCS performance and adaptability. Levine et al. (2016) demonstrated the potential of deep reinforcement learning for robotic control tasks, showcasing the ability of learning-based approaches to handle complex, high-dimensional control problems. This work has inspired ongoing research into the integration of machine learning techniques with traditional control methodologies in networked environments.In conclusion, the field of networked control systems has seen remarkable progress over the past two decades, driven by the increasing integration of cyber and physical systems across various domains. The interplay between control and communication layers, the role of information in estimation and control processes, and the challenges of decentralized decision-making have emerged as key themes in NCS research. As we look to the future, the continued convergence of control theory, information theory, and machine learning promises to unlock new possibilities for robust, efficient, and intelligent networked control systems.
